description: Pen-and-ink and watercolor, on vellum. Each double-page illumination is 21 x 29 cm. Compass rose on inside back cover. Dedicated to Hieronymus Ruffault, Abbot of St. Vaast. Title provided by cataloger. "Maps 1, 2, and 10 show America. No. 1 shows the Gulf of California which Ulloa discovered in 1539. On the same map Yucatan is shown as an island, and the east and west coasts of North and South America are only partially shown. On no. 2, the east coasts of North and South America are shown in their entirety and the west coasts only partially. Clumps of trees in green and gold are shown on no. 1, near the Noluccas, and on no. 2, in the Brazilian region of South America. The oval world map (no. 10) shows Magellan's route around the world and a route from Spain to Peru. The 12 wind cherubs on this map are named." -- Ristow and Skelton, Nautical charts on vellum in the Library of Congress, 1977. LC Nautical charts on vellum, 5 Rosenthal 1914, 1884 Ruge 1916, p. 17-18 Wagner 1931, 33 Skelton, 19 LC Luso-Hispanic World, 6 Phillips, 5914 Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image.

notes: Each double-page illumination is 21 x 29 cm. Compass rose on inside back cover.
Dedicated to Hieronymus Ruffault, Abbot of St. Vaast.

"Maps 1, 2, and 10 show America. No. 1 shows the Gulf of California which Ulloa discovered in 1539. On the same map Yucatan is shown as an island, and the east and west coasts of North and South America are only partially shown. On no. 2, the east coasts of North and South America are shown in their entirety and the west coasts only partially. Clumps of trees in green and gold are shown on no. 1, near the Noluccas, and on no. 2, in the Brazilian region of South America. The oval world map (no. 10) shows Magellan's route around the world and a route from Spain to Peru. The 12 wind cherubs on this map are named." -- Ristow and Skelton, Nautical charts on vellum in the Library of Congress, 1977.

description: Relief shown pictorially. Some maps entirely in Italian, some maps entirely in Latin. Title derived by cataloger from title page of bound Lafréry atlas. Seventeen loose sheets that appear in atlases sold by Antoine Lafréry. Phillips, 5917 Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image.

contents: [1] Septemtrionalium regionum Suetiae Gothiae Norvegiae Daniae et terrarum adiacentium recens exactaq. descriptio Michaelis Tramezini formis ex pontificis Max. ac Veneti senatus in proximum decenmium privilegio 1558.  Iacobus Bussius Belga in aes incidebat -- [2] A benigni lettori di M. Iacomo Castaldo ui si rapresenta la prima parte della descrittione del regno di Polonia, con la sua scala di miglia intagliata da Paolo Furlani veronese al segno della Colonna, Venetia l'anno  1568 -- [3] Il uero disegno della seconda parte dil regno di Polonia dell'eccmo. M. Giacomo Gastaldo piamontese in Venezia l'anno 1568. Intagliata da Paolo Forlani veronese al segno della Colonna inmerzaria -- [4]  Il disegno particolore delle regioni che sono da Constantinopoli a Venetia, da Venetia a Viena ... opera noua di Iacomo Gastaldi  piamōtese ... Fabius Licinius fecit -- [5] De Maiorica insvla, De Minorica insvla -- [6] Novo et vero dissegno della Marca di Ancona con le svi confini. In Venetia apresso Gioan Francesco Camario al segno della piramide -- [7] Sacra Tvscia -- [8] Nova descriptio ne del Frivli, 1561 -- [9] Territorio di Roma

[10] Regno di Napoli. Alla libraria della stella in Venetia, 1557 -- [11] Regno di Napoli -- [12] Melita nunc Malta. Li porti dell'Isola di Malta con la pianta della noua cittade dove habiteranno quelli che stanno hora nel Borgo qui disegnato. Romae 1563, cum gratia et priuilegio -- [13] Roma. Sebastianus a Regibus Clodiensis in aere incidebat, 1561 -- [14] Nvovo et verissimo ritratto del isola di Malta tramontana. Palumbi Nouarien curabant, Romae 1565 -- [15] Paulus de Furlanis Veronensis opus hoc exmi. cosmographi dui Iacobi Gastaldi pedemontani instaurauit et dicauit exti. iur. et docti. ut aurato aequiti  dno. Paulo Michaeli Vincentino. Venetiis Ioan. Francisci Camottii aeris formis ad signum pyramidis, anno 1560 -- [16] La uera descrittione della nauigatione di tutta l'Europa et parte dell'Affrica et dell'Asia quali confinano con elsa. Fatta con ogni diligentia dall'eccellente cosmografio signor Giacomo Homé portoghese ... in Roma 1572. Ex typis Antonÿ Lafreri -- [17] Tramontana. Opera di Jacopo di Gastaldi, cosmografo. In Venetia 1552 cu[m] priuileg. In Venetia appresso Gabriel Giolito, al segno delle Fenice.
notes: Some maps entirely in Italian, some maps entirely in Latin.
Title derived by cataloger from title page of bound Lafréry atlas.
Seventeen loose sheets that appear in atlases sold by Antoine Lafréry.
Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image.

description: Scale not given. Manuscript, pen-and-ink and watercolor. Most of the plans are oriented with north to the top. This is the first in a series of plans of the camps of Comte de Rochambeau's army during the march north from Williamsburg, Va., to Boston, July-December 1782. The soldiers marched in four divisions, each a day's march apart, consequently the camps shown were occupied for four or more nights. Most of the plans are oriented with north to the top. They are bound under the title Amérique campagne 1782: plans des differents camps occupés par l'armée aux ordres de Mr. le Comte de Rochambeau. This volume once belonged to Rochambeau himself. It was purchased by the Library of Congress in 1883 and comprises part of the Rochambeau Collection. The entire set of plans is reproduced in Rice and Brown, American campaigns of Rochambeau's army (1792), v.2. LC Maps of North America, 1750-1789, 1477-1491 Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image. Vault AACR2: 440; 650

contributors: Rochambeau, Jean-Baptiste-Donatien de Vimeur, comte de, 1725-1807.
notes: Most of the plans are oriented with north to the top.

This is the first in a series of plans of the camps of Comte de Rochambeau's army during the march north from Williamsburg, Va., to Boston, July-December 1782. The soldiers marched in four divisions, each a day's march apart, consequently the camps shown were occupied for four or more nights.
Most of the plans are oriented with north to the top.
They are bound under the title Amérique campagne 1782: plans des differents camps occupés par l'armée aux ordres de Mr. le Comte de Rochambeau.
This volume once belonged to Rochambeau himself.
It was purchased by the Library of Congress in 1883 and comprises part of the Rochambeau Collection.
The entire set of plans is reproduced in Rice and Brown, American campaigns of Rochambeau's army (1792), v.2.
Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image.
